intro: Sinapis persoonii, commonly known as Persian mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to the Middle East and Central Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other mustard plants and cruciferous vegetables. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring alternate, pinnately lobed leaves and bright yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its small, triangular pods contain several seeds, which are used in traditional medicine and as a spice. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid regions.
